snippet: The delicate wordplay of Nöel Coward and Cole Porter is the focus of “Mad Dogs and Educated Fleas” in the Lyrics & Lyricists series at the 92nd Street Y.
abstract: Stephen Holden reviews performance of songs by Noel Coward and Cole Porter at the 92nd Street Y, as part of its Lyrics & Lyricists series. (M)
lead_paragraph: ''An avalanche of words'' is how Mark Waldrop, the host of the Lyrics & Lyricists program ''Mad Dogs and Educated Fleas: Nöel and Cole, a Battle of Wits'' described the program at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday evening. By the end of the two-and-a-half-hour show, the Kaufmann Concert Hall was half-buried in drifts of refined light verse invented eons before ''whatever,'' ''no problem,'' ''awesome'' and ''dude'' dominated everyday language. This was the first time Mr. Waldrop, a frequent behind-the-scenes director of many Lyrics & Lyricists shows, stepped to the fore; he appeared stiff and flustered. Ignoring its subjects' great love songs, the show concentrated on their wittier lyrics sung and recited by a mostly well-chosen cast accompanied by a backup quartet led by the pianist Don Rebic.

headline.main: From Coward and Porter, a Night of Songs Witty, Wistful and Wise
